docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: A collection of notes of changes to be done to a distro post-install.

docs.title: Welcome to MkDocs
docs.text: For full documentation visit mkdocs.org.

docs.title: Commands
docs.text:
• mkdocs new [dir-name] - Create a new project.
  • mkdocs serve - Start the live-reloading docs server.
  • mkdocs build - Build the documentation site.
  • mkdocs -h - Print help message and exit.

docs.title: Project layout
docs.text:
mkdocs.yml    # The configuration file.
docs/
    index.md  # The documentation homepage.
    ...       # Other markdown pages, images and other files.

docs.title: Lineage
docs.text:
• Arch
  • Manjaro

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
• A very nice distro whith updates much closer to pure arch. That can be a good or bad thing depending on how risk averse you are.
  • Can be very thick, meaning lots of packages are installed by default.

docs.title: Latte
docs.text: It's very nice, but not my taste. I do like the general setup so I will borrow from it and mimic it using Plasma native panels.

docs.title: Before you start
docs.text:
• You will lose the use of the META key used to launch the application launcher. There's fix for this described at the end.
  • Quit Latte
  • This is to keep Latte out of the way while the new layout is being setup.
  • In the event you're not happy with the setup, you will have something to work with until you sort things out or get rid of the native panels.
  • Be prepared for a mess of a UI if you've setup some new panels as Latte may overlap them when it loads.

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
• Add a default panel to the bottom.
  • Add an empty panel to the top.

docs.title: Default panel
docs.text:
• Configure to your liking
  • My personal choices
  • Dashboard launcher
  • Virtual Desktop pager
  • Icons only task manager
  • Peek at desktop

docs.title: Empty panel
docs.text:
• Configure to your liking
  • My personal choices
  • Window Title
  • Spacer
  • Thermal monitor
  • System Monitor: Network Speed
  • Network Speed widget
  • Media Player
  • System Tray

docs.title: Finalize & Clean Up
docs.text:
• Uninstall Latte
  • Restore use of meta key to trigger application launcher.
  • Restore window titlebars

docs.title: Uninstall Latte
docs.text: • Use you preferred package manager and remove Latte

docs.title: Restore META key
docs.text:
• Back up the file ~/.config/kglobalshortcutsrc.
  • Use your preferred editor and modify the file.

Before:

Meta=org.kde.lattedock,/Latte,org.kde.LatteDock,activateLauncherMenu

After:

# Meta=org.kde.lattedock,/Latte,org.kde.LatteDock,activateLauncherMenu

N.B. The line will get removed from the file on next reboot.

docs.title: Restore window title bars
docs.text:
• Back up the file ~/.config/kwinrc.
  • Use your preferred editor and modify the file.

Before:

BorderlessMaximizedWindows=true

After:

BorderlessMaximizedWindows=false

docs.title: Fan Control
docs.text:
• Modify GRUB: /etc/default/grub
  • Add the following to the Linux default command line parameter.
  • The (...) dots are place holder for what will likely be there, don't remove what's already there, just add the parameter to the end.
GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT= ...

GRUB_CMDLINE_LINUX_DEFAULT= ... acpi_enforce_resources=lax

docs.title: Description
docs.text: Allows setting CPU power & Performance profiles.

docs.title: Discussion
docs.text:
• There is no need to setup the systemd unit (boot time). Especially if you are the sole user.
  • Install CPUPower_Gui and let the user setup the profile as needed.
  • Install global profiles so all users have access to them.

docs.title: Path
docs.text: Global Profile Path: /etc/cpupower_gui.d/ User Profile Path: ~/.config/cpupower_gui/

docs.title: Filenames
docs.text:
<anyname>.profile

I'd strongly recommend naming the file similarly to the intended profile name. The use of spaces is in the filename and profilename are also discouraged, especially if this is your first time.

docs.title: Conservative
docs.text:
Config File: /etc/cpupower_gui.d/Conservative.profile

# name: Conservative

# CPU   Min Max Governor    Online
0-7 800 4000    conservative    True

docs.title: Powersave
docs.text:
Config File: /etc/cpupower_gui.d/Powersave.profile

# name: Powersave

# CPU   Min Max Governor    Online
0-7 1200    3600    powersave   True

docs.title: Boot Time
docs.text: If you'd still like to setup the service to start at boot time see instruction further down. I'd suggest configuring the service first before doing so or just restart it as needed as you make changes.

docs.title: Configure
docs.text:
• Global Config File: /etc/cpupower_gui.conf
  • User Config File: ~/.config/cpupower_gui/00-cpg.conf

N.B. This example assumes you have created the Conservative profile.

[Profile]
profile = Conservative

[GUI]
allcpus_default = True
tick_marks_enabled = True
frequency_ticks = True
energy_pref_per_cpu = False

docs.title: Enable
docs.text: sudo systemctl enable --now cpupower

docs.title: Reload UDEV rules
docs.text: udevadm control --reload-rules && udevadm trigger
